Everything that can be said likely has been--just not the same exact way.

Believing in the statement above is problematic and not conducive to an information-rich internet. If everyone felt that way, no one would have blogs or create articles on blogging platforms.

For the reason above and various others, I've decided to put fingers to keyboard and share my thoughts and views with the world. (Hold your applause.)

As a developer, it would be rare to encounter a bug with a framework or library that someone hasn't already encountered and either (1) posted a work-around, or (2) raised an issue with the framework's creator.

1. It's an excuse to build something

In the development world, many people learn by doing. Developers go to hackathons to build things; they build their family members things; they build things for themselves. Sometimes, the usefulness of these things is dubious. This isn't unusual, but it's OK.

For me, building something new and on my own time is an opportunity to both check out a new framework and try something new in the world of front-end development. On account of this, I often enjoy the process of selecting something to try out. Sometimes it's as easy as looking at one of those annual developer surveys from StackOverflow, checking out popular JavaScript frameworks, and diving in. Other times my subconscous throws the name of something I've heard of before (Gatsby in this case) to the forefront of my brain and I look it up.

Either way, building something increases my knowledge of common design patterns in development, familiarizes me with different frameworks, and gives me a chance to use something outside of my day-to-day work.
